abstracts.cdata!:
As El Salvador grappled with the impact
            of external shocks in 2008 and 2009, it turned to the World
            Bank for financial and technical assistance to strengthen
            its financial management and protect social programs that
            are critical to the poorest people across the country. With
            the support of the International Bank for Reconstruction and
            Development, the government was able to both improve its tax
            revenues and also increase key social programs that reached
            nearly 100,000 households, as well as boost secondary school
            enrollment by more than 38,000 students.
